rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Prof. Glish is a good professor, but CHEM 241H was pretty tough with him. Although we had a "curve" for each individual exam, it wasn't much really of a help to our grade compared to the regular CHEM 241. I would highly suggest taking regular CHEM 241 if you can.
Prof Glish is a really awesome guy. Very approachable and nice sense of humor. His tests are straightforward--do the book problems. Generous curve as well. Recommend!

Never heard of Glish prior to taking his Chem 241 class, but he quickly turned into my favorite teacher at UNC.  Must do all readings and work tons of problems.  Very approachable if you have any questions and is fair about point-spreads and test curves.  Tests will challenge you and you review old material for the final. Got a B. Recommend.

If he taught just a little bit, he'd make this class less painful. During lectures, he basically goes over the content of his power point slides... I don't think, he realizes how much hatred he induces in us towards the course.

I had Glish back in the day.  He looked at my grades and said there were no way I could get an A.  Luckily, if we scored an A on the final we got an A (I got an A).  His teaching was not that great and the book was more clear than him.
Absolutely terrible.  Avoid if you can.

Posts lectures online, but should attend class for bonus points, class is boring but not unbearable.  DO HOMEWORK PROBLEMS, although they are lengthy and not easy, you will learn the material and the problems frequently appear on the exams with slightly different numbers or wording so its worth it.
No Comments

This class was ok.  Lecture was pretty much just power points posted on blackboard beforehand.  To keep students involved in lecture he would have multiple choice with remotes to respond in order to earn extra credit.  Test were on the harder side, be sure to study old tests!
His tests are very tricky!

Can not keep his politics and teaching separate. Validates opinions by saying he has an economics degree. Has in class questions and jeopardy for extra credit. Teaches quickly, lectures do not prepare you for tests. Must teach yourself. Optional homework.
